document_metadata.description: A knowledge assembly of biological entities associated with mossy fibers and their relation to epilepsy.
document_metadata.name: Epilepsy - Mossy Fibers

links.evidence: A down-regulation of mGlu2/3 protein expression at the mossy fiber pathway was associated with a significant reduction in mGlu2/3 protein expression in the hippocampus and cortex of chronically epileptic rats.

links.evidence: Mossy fiber sprouting correlated with granular layer NGF immunoreactivity and seizure frequency.

A down-regulation of mGlu2/3 protein expression at the mossy fiber pathway was associated with a significant reduction in mGlu2/3 protein expression in the hippocampus and cortex of chronically epileptic rats.

A down-regulation of mGlu2/3 protein expression at the mossy fiber pathway was associated with a significant reduction in mGlu2/3 protein expression in the hippocampus and cortex of chronically epileptic rats.

To explore the effects of the ultrastructural features of sprouted mossy fiber synapses in the mechanism of temporal lobe epilepsy. The time course of the increase of netrin-1 mRNA in the dentate granule cell layers was correlated with the time course of mossy fiber sprouting and synaptic reorganization in hippocampus. The axon guidance molecule- netrin-1 plays an important role in the process of mossy fiber axonal outgrowth and synaptogenesis in the hippocampal dentate gyrus.

Our results suggest that the long-term adverse effects of recurrent neonatal seizures on cognition and mossy fiber sprouting may be associated with the down-regulated expression of ZnT-1 and CaMK II in hippocampus.

Our results suggest that the long-term adverse effects of recurrent neonatal seizures on cognition and mossy fiber sprouting may be associated with the down-regulated expression of ZnT-1 and CaMK II in hippocampus.

Our results indicate that TRPC3 and TRPC6 participate diversely in synaptic reorganization in the mossy fiber pathway in TLE.

We show that the ligand ephrin-A3 and the receptor EphA5 are expressed in complementary gradients in the adult rat mossy fiber system.

links.evidence: Mossy fiber sprouting correlated with granular layer NGF immunoreactivity and seizure frequency.

To explore the effects of the ultrastructural features of sprouted mossy fiber synapses in the mechanism of temporal lobe epilepsy. The time course of the increase of netrin-1 mRNA in the dentate granule cell layers was correlated with the time course of mossy fiber sprouting and synaptic reorganization in hippocampus. The axon guidance molecule- netrin-1 plays an important role in the process of mossy fiber axonal outgrowth and synaptogenesis in the hippocampal dentate gyrus.
GAP43 has been thought to be linked with mossy fiber sprouting (MFS) in various experimental models of epilepsy.

Taken together, these results suggest that the period of robust mossy fiber sprouting does not correlate with the phase of post-lesion BDNF upregulation. Rather, it shows a relationship with the time of upregulation of neurotrophins NGF and NT-3.

Our results suggest that the long-term adverse effects of recurrent neonatal seizures on cognition and mossy fiber sprouting may be associated with the down-regulated expression of ZnT-1 and CaMK II in hippocampus.

Our results suggest that the long-term adverse effects of recurrent neonatal seizures on cognition and mossy fiber sprouting may be associated with the down-regulated expression of ZnT-1 and CaMK II in hippocampus.

These data suggest that the supplementation of FGF-2 and BDNF in an epileptogenic hippocampus may prevent epileptogenesis by decreasing neuronal loss and mossy fiber sprouting, that is, reducing some forms of circuit reorganization.
Our data suggest that a protective mechanism exerted by dynorphin release and activation of kappa receptors may be lost in hippocampi with recurrent mossy fiber sprouting.
Our data suggest that a protective mechanism exerted by dynorphin release and activation of kappa receptors may be lost in hippocampi with recurrent mossy fiber sprouting.
We show that the ligand ephrin-A3 and the receptor EphA5 are expressed in complementary gradients in the adult rat mossy fiber system.

Activation of extrasynaptic NMDAR (comprised of GluN2B>GluN2) dephosphorylates CREB (Ser 133), reduces BDNF expression and triggers neuronal death. Consistent with our hypothesis, chronic treatment (17-21days) of hippocampal slice cultures with the GluN2B-selective antagonists ifenprodil or Ro25,6981 increased both CREB (Ser 133) phosphorylation and granule cell mossy fiber pathway DYN expression

Activation of extrasynaptic NMDAR (comprised of GluN2B>GluN2) dephosphorylates CREB (Ser 133), reduces BDNF expression and triggers neuronal death. Activation of extrasynaptic NMDAR (comprised of GluN2B>GluN2) dephosphorylates CREB (Ser 133), reduces BDNF expression and triggers neuronal death. Consistent with our hypothesis, chronic treatment (17-21days) of hippocampal slice cultures with the GluN2B-selective antagonists ifenprodil or Ro25,6981 increased both CREB (Ser 133) phosphorylation and granule cell mossy fiber pathway DYN expression

Our results suggest that TrkA, but not p75NTR, plays a role in kindling, while both receptors modulate kindling-induced mossy fiber sprouting. This implicates different mechanisms of neurotrophin action on kindling (mediated by TrkA) and neuronal sprouting (mediated by both TrkA and p75NTR) and suggests that sprouting involves kindling-independent neurotrophin action via p75NTR.

Our results suggest that TrkA, but not p75NTR, plays a role in kindling, while both receptors modulate kindling-induced mossy fiber sprouting. This implicates different mechanisms of neurotrophin action on kindling (mediated by TrkA) and neuronal sprouting (mediated by both TrkA and p75NTR) and suggests that sprouting involves kindling-independent neurotrophin action via p75NTR.

These data suggest that the supplementation of FGF-2 and BDNF in an epileptogenic hippocampus may prevent epileptogenesis by decreasing neuronal loss and mossy fiber sprouting, that is, reducing some forms of circuit reorganization.

Cdk5/p35 and its substrate tau protein may be involved in MFS. Understanding the molecular mechanisms of MFS may lead to therapeutic interventions for limiting epileptogenesis.
